From eggs to either adult workers, 
queens or drones: How? 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
Describe 
the 4 stages of development: egg, larvae, pupa, adult 
Compare 
and contrast the different morphs/casts in development, 
morphology and behavior 
Explain 
the relative role of genetics and environment/epigenetics on 
caste determination 
Summarize 
how female larvae can become either workers or queens, 
and articulate the role of epigenetic modifications in this process

But how does the queen decide whether she 
should “sprinkle” her eggs or not? 
Queens explore the comb and examine the size/shape of the cell 
shaped by the worker, then lay eggs that are either diploid (fertilized) 
or haploid (not fertilized)

Queen cells: peanut shaped cells that are hanging vertically from the comb
